title: 106_s2605
content: The "Commercial Fishermen Safety and Tax Fairness Act of 2000" allows income averaging for fishermen by amending the Internal Revenue Code to include fishing business. The definition of elected farm income now includes fishing business, and a new definition for fishing business is provided as the conduct of commercial fishing as defined in the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act. The Commercial Fishermen Safety and Tax Fairness Act of 2000 includes a new section in the Internal Revenue Code for a Fishing Safety Equipment Credit under SEC. 45D. The Fishing Safety Equipment Credit allows eligible taxpayers engaged in a fishing business to claim a credit of 75% of qualified fishing safety equipment expenses, not exceeding $1,500. Qualified expenses include lifesaving equipment required on vessels. The Fishing Safety Equipment Credit pertains to lifesaving equipment required on vessels for fishing businesses. Special rules and aggregation rules apply, and no double benefit deduction is allowed. The basis of equipment is adjusted if a credit is claimed. The Fishing Safety Equipment Credit allows for a basis adjustment of equipment when a credit is claimed. Additionally, there is a limitation on carrying back the credit and conforming amendments to the Internal Revenue Code. The Fishing Safety Equipment Credit allows for a basis adjustment of equipment when a credit is claimed under section 45D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes amendments to subsection (a) of section 1016 and a clerical amendment to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The Fishing Safety Equipment Credit under section 45D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2000.
